images.caption: Figure 1:An example that illustrates how post-processing truncates redundant parts at the end of generation.𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾\mathsf{middle}sansserif_middleis generated by the model, which introduces syntax error and breaks correctness if directly connected to𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑\mathsf{suffix}sansserif_suffix. After truncating the part with strike-through through post-processing,𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾\mathsf{middle}sansserif_middlesuccessfully connects to𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑\mathsf{suffix}sansserif_suffixwithout any errors.

Figure 2:An example showing that FIM requires planning capabilities.𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾\mathsf{middle}sansserif_middleinReferencerefers to the ground truth and𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾\mathsf{middle}sansserif_middleinAnswerrefers to the code generated by LLMs, given𝗉𝗋𝖾𝖿𝗂𝗑𝗉𝗋𝖾𝖿𝗂𝗑\mathsf{prefix}sansserif_prefixand𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑\mathsf{suffix}sansserif_suffix. Compared with the ground truth, LLM fails to connect to𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑𝗌𝗎𝖿𝖿𝗂𝗑\mathsf{suffix}sansserif_suffixdue to lack of planning capability.

Figure 3:Overview of Horizon-Length Prediction (HLP). In this example, we set the length of𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾\mathsf{middle}sansserif_middleto five tokens. Following the flow of arrows, we illustrate how the second token of𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾𝗆𝗂𝖽𝖽𝗅𝖾\mathsf{middle}sansserif_middle(i.e.,"x2subscript𝑥2x_{2}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT") is processed through both next-token prediction objective and horizon-length prediction objective.

header: 5Next-Token Prediction Alone Cannot Yield Horizon Awareness
